Fig 44 Existing vs. Finished grade

[Illustration of a house side elevation with dashed lines indicating ground levels and height measurements]

Height: measured to top of roof material of the highest peak

Existing grade (before fill)
Lowest point of ground elevation before fill (existing grade) adjacent to the structure

Fig 45 Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%

[Illustration of two houses on a slope with dashed lines indicating existing grade (before fill), finished grade, and height measurements]

30' above finished
Height

The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope

Fig 46 Comparison of different grades

[Graph with lines labeled 1:10 10%, 3:10 30%, 5:10 50%, 10:10 100%]

47

visual_elements.description: A table with four columns labeled 'When measuring', 'Use', 'Which is defined as', and 'Illus.'. It defines how to measure grade for structures on land with natural slope ≤ 10%, > 10%, and defines a daylight plane with references to figures for illustration.

Side elevation drawing of a house showing existing grade (before fill), finished grade (after fill), and height measured to the top of roof material of the highest peak. Labels indicate the lowest point of ground elevation before fill adjacent to the structure.

Diagram showing two houses on a slope greater than 10%, with dashed lines indicating existing grade (before fill) and finished grade. Height limits are marked as 30' above existing grade and 30' above finished grade. A note states the structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope.
Graph comparing different grades with lines labeled 1:10 (10%), 3:10 (30%), 5:10 (50%), and 10:10 (100%). The graph uses a grid background to show slope steepness.

technical_specifications.parameter: Natural slope for existing grade measurement
Height limit above existing grade on slopes > 10%
Height limit above finished grade on slopes > 10%

additional_notes: All text is clear and legible.
No handwritten annotations or stamps present.
Page number 47 at bottom right corner.
